meta.subject: Art and Design
meta.source: SQA Higher Art and Design course specification

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: A mark that can outline shapes, show direction, or create texture and movement.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to line to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: A flat area enclosed by lines or edges, such as geometric or organic shapes.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to shape to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: A three dimensional quality, showing volume and depth.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to form to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: How light or dark something is, used to create depth and contrast.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to tone to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: The surface quality of something, real or suggested through marks and pattern.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to texture to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: The use of hue, saturation and brightness to create mood, contrast or harmony.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to colour to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: A repeated arrangement of shapes, lines or colours.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to pattern to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: The area around, within and between forms and shapes, including positive and negative space.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to space to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: How visual elements are arranged to create balance and focus.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to composition to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: A sense of visual stability created by distributing elements across the work.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to balance to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: A strong difference between elements (such as light and dark or rough and smooth) used to add impact.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to contrast to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: The relative size and scale of parts within an image or design.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to proportion to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: How big or small something appears, often in relation to the viewer or other elements.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to scale to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: Making an element stand out as a focal point through contrast, placement or scale.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to emphasis to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: A sense that the parts of a work belong together and create a coherent whole.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to unity to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: Techniques for showing depth and distance on a flat surface.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to perspective to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: How text and images are arranged on a page or screen to communicate clearly.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to layout to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: The style and arrangement of text, including font choice, size and spacing.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to typography to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: How something looks and feels visually, including style and appeal.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to aesthetics to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: The materials used to make work (for example, pencil, paint, ink, digital tools).
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to media to explain what it does.

cards.subject: Art and Design
cards.back: A practical method used to handle media and create effects.
cards.use: When analysing your own work, you can point to technique to explain what it does.
